reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: United Nations ’Flights of Mercy’ in Yemen

description.narrative:
Main changes: a) Revision of the number of patients admitted for care and treatment abroad (from 200 to 100 based on the changes to the budget presented in the budget modification request form). b) Change in the route. The air transport will be made available to eligible patients and a medical travel companion – both of whom must be cleared as ‘fit-to-fly’ from Sana’a to Cairo. The stop-over in Bisha (KSA) will no longer be required as per last coordination with the concerned parties and partners involved in the preparation of the FoM. Patients and medical travel companions will be flown from Cairo, back to Sana’a starting one month after the first flight departs to Cairo. c) Updated risk matrix (this file was uploaded in the original request of GA modification as annex and is available at the "Documents" section).
Main changes as part of 10 March 2020 1) Change in location. According to the original project, patients would be transferred to Cairo (Egypt). Since the start of the project, the authorization from the national authorities in Egypt required additional interaction and coordination in parallel, the Kingdom of Jordan offered to facilitate the transfer and treatment of the patients. Given the life-saving nature of this special project, and with the aim of assisting families in dire need of treatment, WHO and other partners involved in this project concurred on expanding the access to medical treatment, including Amman (Jordan) as additional location. As a result of this change: 1.1) 28 patients that are seeking care for the 12 conditions (eligibility criteria) are currently in Amman as either in-patients or outpatients. Travel companions are also seeking medical care and will be recorded as patients, once the patient tracker is completed by International SOS. 1/2) Between 50 – 70 patients are expected to travel to Cairo, subject to clearances for each case, once the list of patients is finalized and submitted to the Egyptian authorities for review. 1.3) Based on the feasibility study conducted by International SOS for medical care in Amman, the average cost per patient is estimated at US$ 36,556 per patient, compared to US$31,500 per patient in Cairo. This point of information confirms that the change of location does not entail cost savings.
2) Change in project duration/No Cost Extension (NCE). The organization of each Flight of Mercy entails the concurrence of multiple stakeholders. The preparation and take -off of the next flight are likely to happen in March - April, beyond the time frame of the current OCHA-funded project. The NCE will enable WHO to secure the institutional buy-in needed for the successful organization of the next flight that will take patients to Egypt.
3)An update on the status of the expenditures and funds committed to pay INTERNATIONAL SOS and WFP is annexed with explanatory notes.
Update as of 15 March 2020 WHO Yemen Country Office has reached out OCHA team sharing the following request: In light of the last72 hours changes related to closure of the airports due to COVID19, including Jordan, we have been considering to modify the GA until 31 October 2020 instead of 30 June 2020. Given the current COVI19 situation, it will take time to reactivate the project and ensure the next flight can take place by June 2020. In light of the above, WHO Yemen has requested OCHA concurrence to process the NCE with end date 31 OCT 2020. It would be more efficient to go for one NCE until 31 OCT 2020 rather than processing a next NCE in May-June, given the current operational context associated to COVID 19.

description.narrative: Health - Social Affairs - Health - policy, planning and administration

In the midst of instability, it is the vulnerable in our society who are often most affected.
We are currently mobilizing to provide supplies to Southern Californian clinics that are responding to the disaster. These supplies include n-95 masks, gloves, isolation gowns, and more. Professionals who are testing for the virus rely on the isolation gowns to safely test individuals without getting sick themselves. GCH is working to ensure that these clinics will have everything they need to operate safely and efficiently. We also will continue to provide food to low-income students throughout Southern California. This is especially necessary at this time because many will be losing the free and reduced meals they typically receive at their school each day.
Help us respond to urgent needs throughout Orange and LA Counties. With volunteer groups postponing their services and donors being hesitant, we are asking for your help to support our mission through this difficult season.
Together we can ensure that our most vulnerable neighbors continue to receive the food they need and that our partner front line agencies have the protection resources to fulfill their missions.

On the first day of school closures in Orange County, Giving Children Hope packed and delivered enough bulks pallets of food to feed over 1,300 local families for a week! Giving Children Hope is in communication with all our school partners and is committed to safely delivering food to our We've Got Your Back families. Food was delivered today to the following school districts:
Buena Park Centralia Santa Ana Magnolia Anaheim Union In addition, we distributed critical medical supplies such as masks, gloves, isolation gowns, and sanitation products to five community clinics. All of the clinics listed below were in short supply of these items necessary to safely administer corona virus testing.
North Orange County Regional Health Foundation KCS Families Together of Orange County Community Health Center Serve The People Southland Integrated Services
Lisa Shelton-Finch, CEO of North Orange County Regional Health Foundation said: "Thank you. Our staff was elated to see the box this morning. It truly helped to put their fears at ease that they will have the PPE needed to protect themselves and our patients."

description.narrative: Total project budget

CEPI’s mission is to stimulate and accelerate the development of vaccines against emerging infectious diseases and enable access to these vaccines for people during outbreaks. The budget presented in this activity includes all investments + operating expenses and financial costs. • CFP1 on priority pathogens for EIDs: Launched January 2017 for the diseases Lassa, Nipah and MERS. The decision on priority diseases departed from pathogens identified by the WHO Blueprint for Action, followed by an in-depth assessment by the SAC. In recommending priority diseases to the CEPI Board, the SAC applied criteria related to 1) public health impact (potential of outbreak, transmissibility, burden of disease) and 2) feasibility (current scientific knowledge, pipeline candidates available). • CFP2 on platform technologies: Launched October 2017 to enable rapid vaccine development against both known and unknown pathogens that trigger infections with epidemic potential. A requirement is to produce sufficient vaccine doses to impact an emerging outbreak and that the platform demonstrates versatility one of the priority pathogens from the WHO Blueprint list. • CEPI’s third call for proposals (CfP3i) was for the development of human vaccines against Rift Valley fever and Chikungunya diseases. Rift Valley fever disease is included among the WHO R&D Blueprint list of priority pathogens in 2018, while Chikungunya is deemed to present a major public health risk where further R&D is needed. The call for proposals closed on March, 2019. • In addition CEPI has made calls for Biological standards and assays, Data collection and Scientific research. • In 2020 CEPI launched a new call for proposals to develop vaccines against novel coronavirus, COVID-19. CEPI will strive to include more details the coming months and years.

PEF has substantial experience in designing and overseeing the implementation of technical water and environmental infrastructure -and will lead on overseeing the soft component of the action, working closely with the Oxfam focusing on implementation ofactivities in the southern governorates of Gaza strip. PEF has substantial experience in community mobilisation, hygiene promotion, and massmedia campaigns in addition to designing and overseeing the implementation of water and environmental projects -and will lead on implementing the community mobilization actions, rehabilitation and general maintenance of the WASH facilities and installation of the renewal energy (solar system).

participating-org.narrative: The Palestinian Environmental Friends Association is a non-profit organization (Nongovernmental Organization). It was establishmentin 1998 by a group of Palestinian experts to meet the demand needed in the field of the environment and natural resources.The establishment of PEF enables environmental friends all over the world to cooperate neglecting geological and political constrains to stopthe negative impacts on the environment. Together, we create a universal free from pollution, sustainable and suitable for new generations. PEF practiced projects almost all over Gaza Strip. The projects activities mainly covered the following areas: Water and wastewater, public health, global warming, infrastructure and capacity building activities, compost production, solid wastes and awareness programs. The association aim is to share in improving the environmental situation in the Palestinian territories, also, to protect the local environment, and public health natural resources from pollution and mining. Public awareness <(>&<)> environmental education is one of the organization aims to have sustainable and well-managed natural resources in addition of rehabilitation of Water and Sewerage Infrastructure in Northern Gaza Governorate . PEF aims to have a wide range ofcooperation with local, regional and international organizations and individuals share its aims and activities

Youth Empowerment Centre (YEC) is a not-for-profit, non-governmental, non-partisan, public and voluntary center, which was founded to work in Gaza strip. Oxfam has been working with YEC since 2010 in implementing different WASH projects including; improving public health conditions, supporting vulnerable people in urban areas and linking humanitarian approaches with sustainable resilience in the Gaza Strip. This project is built on several similar interventions implemented by Oxfam, YEC and WASH cluster members during thelast three years, as the proposed activities will cover the identified need of vulnerable families in the eastern area of Gaza governorate who did not benefit from the previous project. Oxfam will work with YEC to ensure access to systems, procedures and standards are in place to achieve effective, high quality delivery.

participating-org.narrative: The YEC was established according to the Ministry of interior license number (8050) in the year 2008 as a youth initiative to meet the community requirements, the YEC was founded to lead children, adolescents, and youth to discover their purpose throughsocial, emotional, mental and physical development opportunities, while promoting positive change in the community.

For that RWDS is planning to prepare hygiene kits for women and distribute among as many women as possible in cooperation with the emergency committees in the targeted areas. RWDS has established a steering committee that consists of members from the General Union of Palestinian Women (GUPW), emergency committees in the targeted areas led by the central emergency committee at the governoratelevel, RWDS women clubs and RWDS staff. All distributions and services are only provided by the emergency committees and in our campaign, the steering committee will support the emergency committee in the distribution of the hygiene kits according to the safety and protection measurements already provided to the emergency committees.

participating-org.narrative:
Rural Women#s Development Society (RWDS) is a Palestinian non-governmental organization working in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Founded in 1987 as the women#s group in Palestinian Agricultural Relief Committees (PARC), RWDS is now independentlyregistered with the Palestinian Authority under RA-287-C.
RWDS has a strong and respected grassroots presence in rural communities and 3000+ women members in a network of 60 women#s clubs. Our unique structure, geographic breadth and large core of dedicated, grassroots volunteers distinguish RWDS from other Palestinian women#s organizations.

PMRS is a member of health cluster which includes all national and international healthcare actors. PMRS, therefore, has access toinformation and provides the health cluster#s coordinator and the WHO with key updates and information from their end on adaily basis. Oxfam will provide hygiene and personal protective equipment to both mobile clinics and healthcare centres. PMRS has their own medical staff (physicians and nurses) who are able to detect COVID-19 suspected cases, provide curative support for symptoms, and refer them to MOH emergency committees and the Palestine Red Crescent Society (PRCS) who are responsible to conduct PCR tests and transfer severe cases to designated hospitals.

participating-org.narrative:
PMRS is a grassroots, community-based Palestinian health organization. PMRS was founded in 1979 by a group of Palestinian doctors and health professionals seeking to supplement the decayed and inadequate health infrastructure caused by years of Israeli military occupation. It is non-profit, voluntary, and one of the largest health NGOs in Palestine. PMRS national health programs emphasize prevention, education, community participation, and the empowerment of people.
Since its inception, PMRS has grownfrom a small nucleus of volunteer health workers responding to the increasing healthcare needs in underserved areas, to a leading Palestinian health non-governmental organization (NGO). PMRS now extends its services to over 1.4 million Palestinians in theWest Bank and Gaza Strip, providing improved models of healthcare that are built on sound scientific bases and specifically adapted to the Palestinian context. In the years prior to the Intifada, PMRS made a significant contribution to the creation of aPalestinian national health infrastructure, replacing the fragmented health system inherited from years of Israeli occupation.
PMRS role in health service provision, alongside the Palestinian Ministry of Health (MOH), United Nations Relief and Work Agency (UNRWA) and other health NGOs, has steadily progressed. In light of this, PMRS has established strong links with the public health sector, leading to the creation of a subcontracting system between the MOH and PMRS and other NGOs, such that the MOH canmake use of their health services.
In addition, PMRS has developed its strategy to build model health programs, such as the Womens Health Program, Child Health Program, School Health Program, and Community-Based Rehabilitation (CBR) Program. Based on its considerable experience in service provision; awareness of the needs and characteristics of local communities; professional expertise; and field worker commitment, PMRS develops models and protocols that can be tested in the field, and disseminated topublic and NGO sector institutions – at both local and regional level.
At the same time PMRS is highly involved in policy making at national level, to influence the adoption of legislation that supportscivil society and the creation of a modern democratic state. PMRS works on this with other Palestinian NGOs through the PalestinianNGO network (PNGO) and other joint forums that link between the public and NGO sectors.
PMRS in Gaza employs about 100 people spread between the headquarters in Gaza City, its four clinics, one non communicable diseases (NCD) centre and two rehabilitation centers. The organization also runs two mobile clinics which provide emergency primary health care to communities in marginalized and/or isolated areas. It also conducts awareness activities on various health, hygiene and social issues affecting peoples quality of life. PMRS relies on its network of around 150 volunteers to reach out to all levels of society all over the Strip. First aid teamshave been activated to face the emergency and save lives. Moreover, PMRS has agreements with the Gaza Ministry of Health accordingto which the former refers patients in need of secondary health care to the latter hospitals.

The first face-to-face session of the Organic Leadership Course took place in Ghana between 21-29 April 2018. The objective of the course is to form a new generation of organic local leaders who will contribute to developing the local sector. A total number of 21 participants took part to the first residential session. The main training topics revolved around institutional management, communication, organic value chain, organic services and development, but also an in-depth understanding of the fundamentals of the organic sector. The second face-to-face session took place in October 2018. As part of the graduation process, the participants have created development plan in one of the directions that were explored during the course. Following a competitive selection process, the best three development plans have received a mini-grant of 3000 Euros each. The winners of the grants were announced during the graduation ceremony which took place end of October 2018. The selected projects include a public policy development plan, an organic agriculture training initiative and the set up of a demo farm. The OLC Togo and Burkina Faso were also finalised at the end of 2019, and 3 development plans per country were funded with 3000 euros each. The STP OLC has been scheduled for April 2020, but due to the current Covid-19 pandemic, it will be postponed to a later date.

Excursions abroad are foreseen to principally take place from late Y2/early Y3 onwards once PGS stakeholders in the OM4D countries collected first experiences with PGS processes and can best profit from a learning exchange. In Ghana preparations for an excursion to visit PGS in South Africa have been initiated in April 2019 by the Market-Oriented Agriculture Programme (MOAP) of GIZ in Ghana. MOAP has a source of funding from outside the OM4D project. The PGS team of OM4D is supporting the excursion, e.g. by helping so select sites to visits and connecting the MOAP team with PGS experts in South Africa. Also the participants foreseen by MOAP to join the excursion are the members of PGS committee in Ghana that is supported/initiated by the OM4D project including the OM4D PGS Coordinator in Ghana. In project year 3, the organisation of the two PGS visits continued, with a visit planned for Burkina Faso during the last week of March 2020, and another visit planned for South Africa during 4 -11 May 2020. The PGS visit in Burkina Faso has been unfortunately postponed due to the current Covid-19 pandemic, and it is very likely that also the South African trip will need to be postponed for later this year.

description.narrative: Provide rapid support to the healthcare response to Covid-19, delivering much needed medical equipment and supporting public communications through WHO delivery. Assistance would be directed towards quickly stabilising the fragile healthcare system - which was already overburdened and strained by an economic crisis - at a very crucial time. On top of the underlying pressures, the Government has said the crisis is overwhelming the system. This will be both humanitarian and preventive in nature. WHO assess a significant number of lives could be saved if a severe Covid-19 outbreak can be avoided through proper containment measures; it will also mitigate against secondary instability shocks (particularly amongst vulnerable communities such as Syrian and Palestinian refugees).

title.narrative: Thematic contribution to the World Health Organization (WHO)

description.narrative: Finland contributes one million euros to the World Health Organization's Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan in order to support efforts to response to the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) in developing countries. The objective is to restrain the fur ther spread of Coronavirus in developing countries and to scale up the country readiness and response operations in countries with weaker capacity to identify diagnose and treat cases. The World Health Organization has estimated that resources required glo bally from 1 February to 30 April 2020 will be about 6757 million USD.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Preventing and Responding to the COVID-19 Outbreak

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide timely life-saving health, education and child protection assistance in priority countries in order to contain the global outbreak of the COVID-19 virus. This UNICEF project focuses on 3 of the 8 pillars in WHO's Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan, namely: (i) country-level coordination and monitoring; (ii) risk communication and community engagement; (iii) surveillance, rapid response teams, and case investigation; and (vi) infection prevention and control. UNICEF will also use CERF funds to support adequate health care and nutrition for women, children and vulnerable communities and ensure continuity of services for health, education, nutrition and child protection services. CERF funds will be used to focus on countries with imported cases or that are at high risk of imported cases and have limited operational response capacity. UNICEF is in the process of finalizing the list of target countries, and will communicate this information to CERF shortly.

title.narrative: Early action response to global containment of Novel Coronavirus outbreak

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide timely life-saving health assistance in priority countries in order to contain the global outbreak of the COVID-19 virus. This WHO project focuses on the 8 pillars of WHO's Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan, namely: (i) country-level coordination and monitoring; (ii) risk communication and community engagement; (iii) surveillance, rapid response teams, and case investigation; (iv) points of entry; (v) national laboratories; (vi) infection prevention and control; (vii) case management; and (viii) operational support and logistics. CERF funds will be used to focus on countries with imported cases or that are at high risk of imported cases and have limited operational response capacity.

title.narrative: Preventing and responding to the impact of COVID-19 outbreak on food security

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving food security (agriculture) assistance in 3 countries: Afghanistan, Burkina Faso, Haiti. This FAO project protects agriculture- and livestock-based livelihoods by distributing seeds, animal feed and other agricultural inputs; raises awareness about the transmission of COVID-19; provides protective equipment to prevent the transmission of the disease; mitigates the negative impact of the pandemic through cash distributions; and collects data on the impact of the pandemic on food value chains and agricultural systems.

title.narrative: Mitigating and Responding to the COVID-19 Outbreak in humanitarian settings

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health and sexual- and gender-based violence (SGBV) protection assistance in 8 countries: Afghanistan, Burkina Faso, Chad, Haiti, oPT, South Sudan, Sudan, and Venezuela. This UNFPA project provides essential sexual and reproductive health medical supplies; provides equipment and material for infection prevention and control (including personal protective equipment); ensures safe delivery and access to emergency obstetric and newborn care, clinical management of rape, psychosocial support services, family planning services and availability of contraceptives; provides life-saving SGBV services including medical, psychosocial support and GBV case management; ensures the continuity of supplies, medicines and care for life-saving sexual and reproductive health services; and supports risk communication and community engagement towards primary prevention, contact tracing and stigma reduction.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving camp coordination/camp management, health and protection assistance in 4 countries: Burundi, Libya, Nigeria and Somalia. This IOM project contributes to reducing the transmission the spread of COVID-19, raising awareness about the risks of COVID-19, mitigating the humanitarian and health impact of the outbreak, and ensuring that preventive and adequate preventative measures practices are implemented in camps and camp-like settings and prioritized points of entry.

title.narrative: Global service provision in support of humanitarian/health partners and governments response to the COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide common logistics services to ensure the continuity of life-saving humanitarian operations and health assistance. This WFP project covers the setup and management of one international and two regional logistics staging areas in strategic locations for two months; conducts ten strategic cargo air lifts across a global platform; runs two passenger aircraft for two months to support transport and medical evacuations for humanitarian staff; and establishes three full-equipped treatment centres with a 100-bed capacity each.

This WHO project supports the response actions outlined in WHO's Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan, including detecting and testing suspected cases of COVID-19; preventing and interrupting the transmission of the disease; providing safe and effective clinical care; and ensuring access to essential health services.

title.narrative: Preventing and Responding to the COVID-19 Pandemic

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health, WASH assistance, education and child-protection assistance in 22 countries: Afghanistan, Bolivia, Brazil, Burundi, CAR, Chad, Colombia, Ecuador, Haiti, Iran, Iraq, Libya, Mali, Myanmar, Niger, oPT, Peru, Sudan, Tanzania, Turkey, Ukraine, Venezuela. This UNICEF project strengthens risk communication and community engagement; supports case management including through the provision of criticl medical and WASH supplies; improves infection prevention and control; collects and analyses data on the impacts of COVID-19 on children and women; supports continued access to essential health care and nutrition services for women, children and vulnerable communities; supports access to education and children protection services; and supports access to continuous WASH services for children and their families.

title.narrative: Emergency Response Assistance to the Outbreak of Coronavirus Disease 2019 in China

description.narrative:
The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak was first detected in Wuhan City, Hubei Province, China and continued to expand to other cities in the country. It has a significant impact on people’s lives, health, and overall socioeconomic development of the country. On 30 January 2020, the WHO Director-General announced the outbreak of COVID-19 in China as a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC). Strong international cooperation will be essential at all levels to protect the people and build a safe and healthy future for all.
In order to combat the COVID-19 and win the battle of prevention and control of the contagion, the Chinese government has taken many measures. The demand for medical waste disposal capacity has increased significantly and the emergency disposal capacity of medical wastes in epidemic areas is in urgent need. At the same time, staff dealing with medical waste in hospitals and medical wastes disposal are facing a serious risk of infection, resulting in a shortage of personal protective equipment in the short term. Wuhan and its home province of Hubei are the worst affected regions, calling urgently for assistance from the outside world due to the serious deficiencies in the emergency disposal capacity of medical wastes and personal hygiene protection.
The project was initiated following a request for emergency assistance from the Foreign Environmental Cooperation Centre, Ministry of Ecology and Environment of China (FECO/MEE) regarding the COVID-19 outbreak. UNIDO responded immediately to the request. An understanding on the project objectives, scope, cost estimates and implementation arrangements were reached between UNIDO and FECO/MEE through a tele-conference on February 5, 2020.
This project is designed as an emergency response assistance project to support Hubei province in environmentally sound management of medical wastes, and eventually avoiding the spread of COVID-19.
